  • Factor Indexing
  • Edit on GitHub

Factor Indexingïƒ

Overviewïƒ

The trelliscope package automatically converts factor (categorical) indices from Pythonâ€™s 0-based indexing to R-style 1-based indexing expected by the trelliscopejs viewer.

This critical conversion ensures that categorical filters work correctly in the viewer, preventing the â€œ[missing]â€ bug that occurs when index 0 is incorrectly treated as invalid.

Why 1-Based Indexing?ïƒ

The trelliscopejs-lib viewer was built for R, which uses 1-based factor indexing. The viewer JavaScript code performs:

const label = levels[factor - 1];

This means:

  • Python: factor = 0 â†’ Viewer: levels[0 - 1] â†’ levels[-1] â†’ undefined â†’ â€œ[missing]â€ âŒ

  • Python: factor = 1 â†’ Viewer: levels[1 - 1] â†’ levels[0] â†’ â€œAlgeriaâ€ âœ…

Automatic Conversionïƒ

The conversion happens automatically during JSON serialization in three functions:

  1. _serialize_cog_data() - Converts data for displayInfo.json

  2. write_metadata_json() - Converts data for metaData.json

  3. write_metadata_js() - Converts data for metaData.js

Example Usageïƒ

Numeric Categorical Indices

import pandas as pd
from trelliscope import Display
from trelliscope.meta import FactorMeta

# Create DataFrame with categorical column (0-based indices)
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'country': pd.Categorical(['Algeria', 'Denmark', 'Germany']),
    'value': [100, 200, 300]
})

display = Display(df, name="example")
display.add_meta_variable(
    FactorMeta(varname="country", label="Country",
              levels=['Algeria', 'Denmark', 'Germany'])
)

# Internally: country has indices [0, 1, 2]
# After serialization: cogData has [1, 2, 3]
display.write()

String Factor Values

# Create DataFrame with string column (not categorical)
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'country': ['Algeria', 'Denmark', 'Germany'],  # Strings!
    'value': [100, 200, 300]
})

display = Display(df, name="example")
display.add_meta_variable(
    FactorMeta(varname="country", label="Country",
              levels=['Algeria', 'Denmark', 'Germany'])
)

# Strings automatically converted to 1-based indices:
# 'Algeria' â†’ 1, 'Denmark' â†’ 2, 'Germany' â†’ 3
display.write()

Implementation Detailsïƒ

The conversion logic handles multiple cases:

Numeric Indices (0-based â†’ 1-based)

if isinstance(value, (int, float)) and not (isinstance(value, float) and value != value):
    value = int(value) + 1  # 0 â†’ 1, 1 â†’ 2, etc.

String Values (lookup â†’ 1-based)

elif isinstance(value, str) and hasattr(meta, 'levels') and meta.levels:
    try:
        idx = meta.levels.index(value)  # Find index in levels
        value = idx + 1  # Convert to 1-based
    except (ValueError, AttributeError):
        pass  # Keep string if not in levels

Special Cases

  • NaN/None: Preserved as-is (not converted)

  • Strings not in levels: Preserved as-is

  • Non-factor columns: Unchanged

Data Flow Exampleïƒ

From Python DataFrame to Viewer:

DataFrame (Python)
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ country â”‚ value  â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ 0       â”‚ 100    â”‚  â† Categorical index
â”‚ 1       â”‚ 200    â”‚
â”‚ 2       â”‚ 300    â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

      â†“ Serialization (automatic conversion)

displayInfo.json / metaData.json
{
  "cogData": [
    {"country": 1, "value": 100},  â† 1-based index
    {"country": 2, "value": 200},
    {"country": 3, "value": 300}
  ],
  "metas": [{
    "varname": "country",
    "type": "factor",
    "levels": ["Algeria", "Denmark", "Germany"]  â† 0-indexed array
  }]
}

      â†“ Viewer JavaScript

Viewer Calculation: levels[factor - 1]
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ factor â”‚ Calculation   â”‚ Array Index â”‚ Result   â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ 1      â”‚ levels[1 - 1] â”‚ levels[0]   â”‚ Algeria  â”‚ âœ“
â”‚ 2      â”‚ levels[2 - 1] â”‚ levels[1]   â”‚ Denmark  â”‚ âœ“
â”‚ 3      â”‚ levels[3 - 1] â”‚ levels[2]   â”‚ Germany  â”‚ âœ“
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

Testingïƒ

The factor indexing conversion is thoroughly tested in tests.unit.test_factor_indexing:

  • 17 comprehensive tests covering all conversion scenarios

  • Edge cases: NaN, None, empty DataFrames, unicode

  • End-to-end validation with viewer compatibility

  • 100% test pass rate

See Alsoïƒ

  • /user_guide/categorical_data - Guide to working with categorical data

  • Serialization API - JSON serialization API reference

  • Meta Variables API - Meta variable types

  • Factor Indexing Solution - Technical analysis

Troubleshootingïƒ

Problem: Categorical filter shows â€œ[missing]â€ instead of category names

Solution: This was the original bug, now fixed. If you still see this:

  1. Verify youâ€™re using the latest code (not cached)

  2. Check that factor indices in JSON are integers (not strings)

  3. Confirm indices are 1-based (first value should be 1, not 0)

Verification:

import json

# Check generated JSON
with open('displays/your_display/metaData.json') as f:
    data = json.load(f)

# Should be int with value 1 (not 0, not "0")
print(data[0]['your_factor_column'])  # Expected: 1
print(type(data[0]['your_factor_column']))  # Expected: <class 'int'>
